page.lettertext:
fol.351r
Belgi
[a]
1590 29 Decem
b
To my L. Trea
s
May yt please yo
r
good L. to bee adv
r
tised that I sent you the
[7 of]
this moneth, the long expected awnswere of
e g
na
l states, w
ch
I find
to bee negative too all her
Ma
ties
demaund
, not onely those whertoo they are
not tyed by v
r
tue of
e Treaty, but too ev
r
y matt
r
els, wh
r
unto they are
bound by expresse conditions: To
ceed th
r
upon by way of replie, & too
specifie the wrong
that they offer to her Ma
tie
, I knowe to yo
r
L. it more
then neadeth, & to them yt is in vaine, being bent to
sist in theyr
obstinate cowrse. For yf it bee possible
t
eith
r
by mine owne
experience, or by oth
r
s informac
o
n I should knowe
e disposition & humo
r
of this people, having stood so stiffly so long in a wilfull deniall
of all that is required, I think they will rath
r
hazard
e state of
theyr Countrey, then to bee drawen against theyr willes to alter
theyr purpose. In w
ch
respect, & least my furder dealing should
turne to her Ma
ties
prejudice, I have resolved to bee silent, & too
attend from yo
r
L. what her Hig
nes
will commaund.
We have c
r
taine advertisement, that there are already Embassado
rs
deputed from
e
Empero
r
to propose a generall peace to
e states of
these Provinces. It hath bin thought upon heer, what were fittest to
bee don to p
r
vent the Inconvenience, that may growe upon their coming.
For though they stand not in dout of
e peoples inclination to any
such motion, yet they hold yt best to bee assured, & not to put yt
in
e choise of theyr unconstant disposition. Agayn they are affrayd
as I am secretly enformed, that such conditions of peace may bee
offred unto them, as being knowen unto her Ma
ty
may make her
desyrous to enter into Treaty. For p
r
vention wh
r
of & of all inconveni-
ences, they have resolved to send expressly to
e Empero
r
, & to desire
him to forbeare from sending unto them, for that
e matter of peace
hath bin often debated, & they finde no security in any conditions,
t
the King can propose. they will also write to the
D. of Saxony
the
Electo
r
Palatin
, the
Marques of Brandebourgh
, the
D. of Brunsweke
the
Lantgrave of Hesse
, & to
e
Bishop of Witzbourg
, whose brother is
sayd to bee one of
e Embassado
rs
, to entreat them very earnestly
not to give any eare to
e fraudulent offers of
e Spaniard
but to
ceed to theyr late determination for cleering the Rhine from
forreyn garrisons. all the dout that is conceaved is that the
embassado
rs
wilbee heer, before theyr l
res
come to the Ennemyes
hand
, It is some mens opinion that too lett them come, but
not remayne, & to awnswere to theyr motion w
th
a flatt refusall
were a bett
r
course then
e other & not so subject to offence, Howbeyt
they are minded to write as I have signified./
Wee are heer in good hope
t
the mutinies begon in the Enemyes
garrisons of
Diest
&
Herentals
in
e contrey of
Brabant
who demand
as ys reported for 50 moneths paie, will extend to oth
r
places.
For yt is sayd undoutedly that in
e Enemies Camp, there are many
discontentment
, not for mony matters onely, but for sondry occasyons
w
ch
are greater am
o
g
e greatest then those of meaner quality. It is
also given forth that
e
K. of Spaine
, doth take unto himself the
bestowing of such goverment
& offices of charge, as were accustomed
before to bee given by the
D of Parma
, w
ch
will multiplie men think
the matter of dislike, that is kindled already. We have also
letters from
Andwerp
, that in
e late assembly of the States of those
fol.351v
Bel
gia 1590
Provinces, the Dukes demaunds for contribution have
bene flatly rejected.
There ys no opinion that this winter there wilbee any great matter
attempted by him. For his martiall people are not freed of theyr
mortall diseases wh
r
w
th
they were infected at theyr being in
Fraunce
./
For w
ch
hee hath dispersed them abroade, in
e Land of
Liege
& oth
r
places of rest. Nev
r
theles wee have intelligence at this p
nt
. that to
the nomb
r
of 1200, have entred
e Contrey about
Utrecht
, & don
some small spoile upon the Boores, but retired again w
th
in lesse
then 3 houres, I have sent yo
r
L. heerw
th
the copies of certain
letters, w
ch
were lately intercepted, by the souldiers of
Dergoes
, & being
written in cypher, were lately deciphred by
Mons
r
S
t
Aldegonde
. The
contents of 5 l
res
import not much, yet becaus in some point
the
Ennemyes estat is discovered by them, I thought yo
r
L. would
willingly give them
e reading. The original l
res
were in Spanish
but I have sent them unto yo
u
translated into French. and because I
do p
r
sume that yt might be beneficiall to
e city of
Geneva
, to
see what was written I have sent oth
r
copies unto them. The
vicount of
Turen
, who arrived at
e
Haghe
e 17 of this moneth
hath bin in
e Assembly of
e
gen
r
all States
. & shewed them
e cause of
his going into
Germany
& requ
r
ed theyr help for the intended levies.
All his speeches of her Ma
ty
were full of gratitude & hono
r
, in respect
of her
favours
succors
given to
e King, w
ch
hee declared at some length
& in very good termes. Howbeyt hee had no awnsweare from
e
states, but in generall woordes. That they would deliberate upon his
demaund
& recommend them effectually to
e Provinces, & about
the beginning of
e next moneth deliver theyr resolution to
Mons
r
Buzenval
. By that that I can conjecture by private conference
w
th
my frend
, they will straine theyr estate to advaunce the
action to
e uttermoste. Also
e Vicount hath delt wth mee in
ticul
r
to yeeld what furderance I shalbee able, to w
ch
effect hee did
supose I had bin charged by her Ma
ty
, w
ch
I am not as yet.
Though I dout not therin of her Ma
tyes
pleasure & in that
regard have signified, that my best endevo
r
shall not want.
Of all other matters that may concern these affaires,
S
r
Horace Pallavicine
will adv
r
tise yo
r
L.
for w
ch
I take my
humble leave. Hage. De
c
29 1590.
